The Journal of International Medical Research, 2020; 48: 030006052092568. text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Respiratory
Therapeutics Daily News \-- A new study on Lung Diseases and Conditions -
Asthma is now available. According to news originating from Hebei, People's
Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Fatal asthma is
a rare and potentially fatal disease. This disease requires suitable treatment
to achieve rehabilitation, especially when accompanied by other complications,
such as a silent chest and severe bronchial spasm."

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research, "A 36-year-old man
presented with a 10-year history of asthma that broke out into persistent
asthma attacks and cardiac arrest, and was accompanied by a silent chest for
18 hours. He recovered and was discharged without any sequelae after being
treated by a ventilator, hormones, epinephrine, analgesics, sedation, and
muscle relaxants."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Comprehensive
treatment with a ventilator, hormones, epinephrine, analgesics, sedation, and
muscle relaxants has a good effect on fatal asthma combined with a silent
chest."

For more information on this research see: Successful treatment of fatal
asthma combined with a silent chest: A case report. _The Journal of
International Medical Research_ , 2020;48(5):030006052092568. _The Journal of
International Medical Research_ can be contacted at: Cambridge Med Publ,
Wicker House, High St, Worthing BN11 1DJ, W Sussex, England.

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained
from Q. Zhao, HeBei General Hospital, Hebei, People's Republic of China.
Additional authors for this research include H. Guo, S.Y. Li, X. Xu, N. Xu, C.
Lv, Z.S. Shen and J.G Li.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1177/0300060520925683>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

The publisher's contact information for the _The Journal of International
Medical Research_ is: Cambridge Med Publ, Wicker House, High St, Worthing BN11
1DJ, W Sussex, England.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Asthma Findings from Q. Zhao and Co-Researchers Reported (Successful treatment of fatal asthma combined with a silent chest: A case report): Lung Diseases and Conditions - Asthma
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Respiratory Therapeutics Daily News -- A new study on Lung Diseases and Conditions - Asthma is now available. According to news originating from Hebei, People’s Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Fatal asthma is a rare and potentially fatal disease. This disease requires suitable treatment to achieve rehabilitation, especially when accompanied by other complications, such as a silent chest and severe bronchial spasm.”

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research, “A 36-year-old man presented with a 10-year history of asthma that broke out into persistent asthma attacks and cardiac arrest, and was accompanied by a silent chest for 18 hours. He recovered and was discharged without any sequelae after being treated by a ventilator, hormones, epinephrine, analgesics, sedation, and muscle relaxants.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Comprehensive treatment with a ventilator, hormones, epinephrine, analgesics, sedation, and muscle relaxants has a good effect on fatal asthma combined with a silent chest.”

For more information on this research see: Successful treatment of fatal asthma combined with a silent chest: A case report. The Journal of International Medical Research, 2020;48(5):030006052092568. The Journal of International Medical Research can be contacted at: Cambridge Med Publ, Wicker House, High St, Worthing BN11 1DJ, W Sussex, England.

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Q. Zhao, HeBei General Hospital, Hebei, People’s Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include H. Guo, S.Y. Li, X. Xu, N. Xu, C. Lv, Z.S. Shen and J.G Li.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1177/0300060520925683. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

The publisher’s contact information for the The Journal of International Medical Research is: Cambridge Med Publ, Wicker House, High St, Worthing BN11 1DJ, W Sussex, England.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
